block.p: Russians Say Collision May Have Sunk Submarine Russian officials said that growing evidence of catastrophic damage to their sunken nuclear submarine's hull pointed to a collision with an object or ship. United States officials, who have said no American submarines in the area were involved, have reported that underwater explosions were detected, sounds distinct from those of a collision. Russian rescue teams made more attempts to lock onto a rear escape hatch of the submarine, the Kursk.
The mourning has already begun in the northern Russian port city of Murmansk, which lives off the Russian Navy, as few hold out hope for the lives of the sub's 118 men.

The United States Navy is planning to retire one of its two best undersea rescue vehicles this month in a cost-cutting move that may make it harder to save stricken American submariners, military officials said.

A Death in the West Bank The death of Mahmoud Bazar Abdullah, a prominent Palestinian-American and the uncle of Hassan Abdel Rahman, who is the Palestine Liberation Organization's chief representative in Washington, has raised tensions in the West Bank. Mr. Abdullah, 73, was shot by Israeli soldiers outside his home in a late-night encounter near Ramallah.

Peres Offers Praise for China Former Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel lavishly praised China as he finished a two-day visit intended to bolster Israel's ties with its onetime foe and shore up global support for continued Middle East peace talks.

Hostages' Release Delayed Nine Westerners held for four months by a Muslim rebel group in the Philippines were to have been freed in exchange for a payment that could reach several million dollars, but the release was delayed.

Ailing Tutu Returns Home Archbishop Desmond Tutu, 68, a leading critic of South Africa's former apartheid system, returned to his homeland ''to sleep,'' looking thin and frail after two years of treatment in the United States for prostrate cancer. The Nobel Peace Prize winner had surgery in November.

Gore Defines Himself And Outlines His Goals Vice President Al Gore made his debut as the Democratic presidential nominee with a vow to work for all Americans, ''especially those who need a voice, those who need a champion, those who need to be lifted up so they are never left behind.''

Mr. Gore's delivery was uncharacteristically brisk as he reeled off causes and issues dear to core Democratic constituencies -- health care, civil rights, affirmative action, public education and abortion rights.
Mr. Gore was headed back to the fund-raising circuit after his speech to the convention, as host of a concert to raise $5.2 million for his party.
Many union officials and union members at the convention remain deeply upset over the China trade deal. Party leaders spent much of the week trying to soothe their feelings.
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's speech on Wednesday drew a larger television audience than did Dick Cheney's in Philadelphia.

Mr. Lieberman refers to himself as an ''observant Jew,'' not Orthodox, a distinction he makes, an aide said, ''because he doesn't follow the strict Orthodox code and doesn't want to offend the Orthodox.''

Bush Agrees to 3 Debates Advisers to Gov. George W. Bush said he would participate in three presidential debates, an announcement intended to blunt criticism from the Gore campaign that Mr. Bush was trying to avoid such face-to-face contests.

New Grand Jury for Clinton Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton's relationship with a White House intern, has empaneled a grand jury to hear evidence, government officials said. The action is part of Mr. Ray's announced intention to consider whether Mr. Clinton should be charged with criminal wrongdoing after he leaves office.

Government Misled Court An F.B.I. agent admitted in federal court that he provided misleading testimony last December that made Wen Ho Lee, left, a Los Alamos scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets, appear deceptive when he had not been.

Heavy Spool of Cable Slips, Badly Injuring 2 in Subway A 7,500-pound spool of electrical cable being lowered by a contractor into the subway station at 14th Street and Eighth Avenue broke loose and barreled down the stairs, gravely injuring two women, ages 73 and 41, officials said.

Trial Ordered in '75 Killing A juvenile court judge in Connecticut ruled that Michael Skakel, 39, should be tried in the 1975 slaying of Martha Moxley. The judge must next decide whether Mr. Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy's, should be tried as an adult. Conviction as an adult could bring a life sentence; conviction as a juvenile would carry a maximum sentence of four years.

Hearing on Pesticide An E.P.A. toxicologist, Dr. Brian Dementi, who criticized a preliminary agency report this year that said malathion showed little evidence of being harmful to humans, made his case to an independent panel of scientists assembled by the E.P.A. partly in response to his concerns.

A Charter School's Decline New Covenant, lavished with praise by Governor Pataki when it opened in Albany last September, is being threatened with loss of its charter by state regulators concerned by its students' poor performance and by upheaval in its management.

Big Fine for Ravens Star The N.F.L. fined Baltimore linebacker Ray Lewis $250,000 for lying to the police about his involvement in an incident that ended with the stabbing deaths of two men outside an Atlanta nightclub after the Super Bowl.

Mixed Verdict in Boxing Case Robert W. Lee Sr., 66, the founder and former president of the International Boxing Federation, was acquitted by a federal jury of major bribery and racketeering charges but convicted of money laundering, tax evasion and interstate travel to aid in racketeering. He could receive up to three years in prison.

Victory for Movie Industry A federal judge in Manhattan ruled that a Web site operator, Eric Corley, and his company, 2600 Enterprises, could not distribute a computer program used to crack codes that prevent the piracy of movies.

Deadline Spurs Phone Talks Negotiators in the Verizon strike sought to resolve issues like job security and mandatory overtime, talking past a midnight deadline in which union representatives of nearly two-thirds of 86,000 striking workers planned to end formal talks.

Deal on Database Is Set Aside A federal bankruptcy judge set aside an F.T.C. plan to limit the ability of an online retailer, Toysmart.com, to sell its customer database as part of its liquidation, even though the data was collected with the promise of confidentiality. The judge said that absent an actual buyer of the data, the F.T.C. action was premature.

Skin Regeneration Study Researchers say skin cells that replace those shed in everyday wear and tear may hide in hair follicles. If confirmed, the finding could improve understanding of skin healing and lead to insights into basal cell carcinoma, a common skin cancer.
